thread.title: After a 6-year closure, Paris' Mankind Museum reopens
thread.title_full: After a 6-year closure, Paris' Mankind Museum reopens - Times Union

author: timesunion.com
title: After a 6-year closure, Paris' Mankind Museum reopens
text:
Photo: Francois Mori, AP Image 1 of / 3 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 3 Visitors look at installation of busts during a press visit at the Museum of Mankind (Musee de l'Homme) in Paris, France, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. Among the thousands of objects and artifacts include the skull of Neanderthal man and of a French philosopher Rene Descartes, the museum, dedicated to anthropology, ethnology and prehistory of human evolution, will open to the public this weekend after six years of renovation. Visitors look at installation of busts during a press visit at the Museum of Mankind (Musee de l'Homme) in Paris, France, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. Among the thousands of objects and artifacts include the ... more Photo: Francois Mori, AP Image 2 of 3 The skull of French philosopher Rene Descartes (1596-1650), top left, is displayed during a press visit at the Museum of Mankind (Musee de l'Homme) in Paris, France, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. Among the thousands of objects and artifacts include the skull of Neanderthal man and of a French philosopher Rene Descartes, the museum, dedicated to anthropology, ethnology and prehistory of human evolution, will open to the public this weekend after six years of renovation. The skull of French philosopher Rene Descartes (1596-1650), top left, is displayed during a press visit at the Museum of Mankind (Musee de l'Homme) in Paris, France, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. Among the ... more Photo: Francois Mori, AP Image 3 of 3 The 28000 years old skull of an Homo Sapiens called "Cro Magnon, The Old Man", found in Dordogne, France, is displayed during a press visit at the Museum of Mankind (Musee de l'Homme) in Paris, France, Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015. Among the thousands of objects and artifacts include the skull of Neanderthal man and of a French philosopher Rene Descartes, the museum, dedicated to anthropology, ethnology and prehistory of human evolution, will open to the public this weekend after six years of renovation. The 28000 years old skull of an Homo Sapiens called "Cro Magnon, The Old Man", found in Dordogne, France, is displayed during a press visit at the Museum of Mankind (Musee de l'Homme) in Paris, France, ... more Photo: Francois Mori, AP After a 6-year closure, Paris' Mankind Museum reopens 1 / 3 Back to Gallery PARIS (AP) — After a six-year closure, and fears over its possible extinction, Paris' Museum of Mankind has reopened following a 92 million-euro ($105 million) renovation.
French President Francois Hollande inaugurated the world-class collection Thursday, which includes the skull of French philosopher Rene Descartes alongside the skull of a Neanderthal man.
"The museum is a hymn to the unity of mankind", Hollande said.
Six rooms show the evolution of man — with 700,000 prehistoric and 30,000 anthropological objects explaining the origins of racial difference, languages and human diversity over millions of years.
Former French President Jacques Chirac removed around half the contents of the museum to fill his landmark legacy project, the Quai Branly museum — and many had voiced doubts about the future of the Museum of Mankind.
